summary: On August 9, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas entered a final judgment against a Texas-based agency that terminated the parental rights of six children.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in San Antonio, Texas, alleges that, on August 10, 2015, the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services removed the children from their mother’s home and placed them in the care of a relative.  According to the complaint, after the relative was removed from the home, the children were left alone with their mother, who was unable to provide for the children. The complaint further alleges that when the relative returned to the home in January of 2017, Mom and Dad continued to visit the children, despite repeated requests from the agency to do so.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against the mother and father of the six children who were at issue in the case.  On August 13, 2016, the trial court entered a judgment against the agency, finding that the agency violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The court also found that the termination was in the best interest of the children and that the department violated Section 161.001(b)(1)(A) and (B).  The court found that, in light of the evidence presented, the termination is in the children's best interest.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint, the agency consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently restrains and enjoins the agency from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders it to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar. The settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-17-17, July 17, 2016.  Separately, the SEC filed a civil action against the Department of Health and Human Services, alleging that, among other things, that the Department violated Section 15(a)(1) and Rule 15b2-1 thereunder, and that it violated Section 17(a) and 17(c) of The Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10 of the Exchange Act and Rule 12b-20 thereunder and Section 15a-3 thereunder; and that, as a result of the Department's actions, the Department has terminated the mother's parental rights to the children in violation of Section 15e-1.
